TokenSource

Extends \DataType

A parameter is composed of a name, type and value.

Example of usage:

or:

author

Yannick Lecaillez
package

phing.types

Methods

Creates an exception that indicates the user has generated a loop of data types referencing each other.

inherited

Response

\BuildException

Configures a TokenReader with the parameters passed to the TokenSource.

configureTokenReader(\TokenReader $reader)

Arguments

$reader

\TokenReader

Create nested <param> tag.

createParam() : \Parameter

Uses standard name/value Parameter class.

Response

\Parameter

Check to see whether any DataType we hold references to is included in the Stack (which holds all DataType instances that directly or indirectly reference this instance, including this instance itself).

dieOnCircularReference( &$stk, \Project $p) : void
inherited

If one is included, throw a BuildException created by circularReference

This implementation is appropriate only for a DataType that cannot hold other DataTypes as children.

The general contract of this method is that it shouldn't do anything if checked is true and set it to true on exit.

throws

Arguments

$stk

$p

\Project

Performs the check for circular references and returns the referenced object.

inherited

Set the value of the refid attribute.

setRefid(\Reference $r) : void
inherited

Subclasses may need to check whether any other attributes have been set as well or child elements have been created and thus override this method. if they do they must call parent::setRefid()

Arguments

$r

\Reference

Creates an exception that indicates that refid has to be the only attribute if it is set.

tooManyAttributes() : \BuildException
inherited

Response

\BuildException

\Reference

Are we sure we don't hold circular references?

checked : boolean
inherited

Subclasses are responsible for setting this value to false if we'd need to investigate this condition (usually because a child element has been added that is a subclass of DataType).

var

Type(s)

boolean

Holds a reference to the project that a project component (a task, a target, etc.) belongs to
